      <title>Designer label Preen launches collection starting at just 65p</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/designer-label-preen-launches-postage-stamp-collection-starting-65p-duchess-cambrige-finella-dress</link>
      <description><p>Catwalk label’s postage stamp collection features Finella dress worn by Duchess of Cambridge</p><p>Preen, the catwalk label designed by the husband and wife team Justin Thornton and Thea Bregazzi and worn by the Duchess of Cambridge and Gwyneth Paltrow, has launched London fashion week’s most affordable collection, with prices starting at just 65p.</p><p>However, the bargain buys are the size of a postage stamp – literally. A six-stamp collection celebrating 20 years of the brand has been issued by the Isle of Man, where both Thornton and Bregazzi grew up. The first-class stamp features the red Finella dress <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/sep/30/the-duchess-of-cambridge-ambassador-of-british-style-post-brexit">worn by the duchess on a royal tour of Canada</a>. The bodycon “Power Dress” that first made the label famous is honoured on another of the stamps.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/designer-label-preen-launches-postage-stamp-collection-starting-65p-duchess-cambrige-finella-dress">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Christopher Bailey bows out from Burberry under a bold rainbow</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/christopher-bailey-bows-out-from-burberry-under-a-bold-rainbow</link>
      <description>An adventurous last show from the form-breaking British designer who reinvented Burberry<p>For 17 years at Burberry, Christopher Bailey has rejoiced in rain. It is, after all, both quintessential British weather and the perfect setting for a trenchcoat. But for his <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/oct/31/christopher-bailey-burberry-transformed-fashion-brand" title="">last catwalk show</a> for London Fashion Week’s biggest brand, the sun came out and Bailey’s reign ended beneath a rainbow.</p><p>The show opened with Adwoa Aboah in rainbow stripes on a white silk skirt and closed with Cara Delevingne under a rainbow fake fur coat. Puffa jackets and hi-top trainers came with rainbow stripes, and a trenchcoat and a blanket cape in a technicolour version of the distinctive beige check. This season the Burberry check is rainbow-hued, a symbol of the firm’s financial support for LGBTQ+ charities.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/christopher-bailey-bows-out-from-burberry-under-a-bold-rainbow">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Michael Halpern dazzles London Fashion Week with platforms and sequins</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/michael-halpern-designer-london-fashion-week-platforms-sequins</link>
      <description><p>The spotlight falls on the designer with a vision is to provide a moment of escapism in dark times</p><p>The question of where fashion sits within the ongoing post-Weinstein cultural awakening feels more pertinent than ever this weekend. Patrick Demarchelier, Princess Diana’s personal fashion photographer, <a href="https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2018/02/16/beauty-and-ugly-truth/c7r0WVsF5cib1pLWXJe9dP/story.html" title="">has denied sexual misconduct accusations</a>. A proposed all-black dress code in support of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/01/times-up-hollywood-women-launch-campaign-to-fight-sexual-harassment" title="">Time’s Up, the campaign against sexual harassment,</a> will dominate the red carpet at the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/jan/09/full-list-of-nominations-for-the-baftas-2018-film" title=""> Bafta awards</a>, an international event that falls in the middle of this week’s London shows.</p><p>For the New York designer Michael Halpern, 30, the timing is perfect. His London-based label Halpern, a cavalcade of sequins and colour, is currently one of the most popular in womenswear. “This idea of inappropriate glamour, or of questioning what is too much in fashion, or goes too far…” Halpern told the <em>Observer</em>, “What’s going on in with women and politics has pushed me to want to make a statement with what I design.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/michael-halpern-designer-london-fashion-week-platforms-sequins">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The beauty bargains that beat the luxury brands | Sali Hughes</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/17/beauty-bargains-that-beat-the-luxury-brands</link>
      <description><p>From micellar water to liquid eyeliner, these top-quality products are a fraction of the price of luxury brands</p><p>I try almost every new micellar cleansing water that comes on to the market, simply because I get through gallons of the stuff. I use it as an eye makeup remover; for sweeping away the hundreds of stripes and smears of testing makeup drawn on my hands each week; for removing the bulk of makeup before proper night-time face cleansing with a balm; for overtired, tipsy cleansing from the comfort of my own bed; and for swift, neat lipstick changes on shoots.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2013/apr/27/sali-hughes-liquid-cleansers">I&nbsp;have tried hundreds</a>, from dirt cheap to silly expensive, and <a href="http://www.boots.com/simple-water-boost-micellar-cleansing-water-400ml-10233099"><strong>Simple’s Water Boost micellar cleansing water</strong></a> (£6.99 for a huge 400ml bottle) is the best at any price. Here is why: unlike many micellars, it doesn’t give me spots. If ever I&nbsp;am testing anti‑blemish treatments on my dry, normally clear face and I use an inferior micellar for a few days, a spot or two will materialise. Not with this – however frequently I&nbsp;use it. It&nbsp;removes everything, even stubborn matte lip stains, with ease. It leaves my skin neither greasy nor tight. It is cheap enough to be used lavishly and has a proper squirty bottle instead of the stupid, wasteful and messy pump dispensers favoured by several luxury brands. At this stage, I&nbsp;see no reason why anyone would pay more.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/17/beauty-bargains-that-beat-the-luxury-brands">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The big picture: London Fashion Week, February 1998</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/big-picture-british-fashion-week-martin-parr</link>
      <description>With the 2018 event now in full swing, we revisit a telling Martin Parr shot from 20 years ago<p>Martin Parr is the kind of quick-witted photographer who catches life on the run, his shutter clicking faster than the human eye can blink. To coincide with London Fashion Week, which began last Friday, here is a deft act of espionage from backstage at the same event 20 years ago. Parr probably didn’t know what he’d snatched until he developed the film and saw that the flustered accidents of a moment had come to rest in a parable, showing how the beauty industry goes about its tortuous, tormenting work.</p><p>Makeup has already transformed the model into a doll: the waxen complexion, with a sickly jaundiced tone around the eyes, and the pursed, painted lips that are smaller and more infantile than her own. Now the hairdressers take over, knotting and coiling and pinning and teasing, with a can of eco-unfriendly aerosol spray ready to freeze her mane. They are technicians, busy on the assembly line; she is their manufactured product, as glassy-eyed as the lens of Parr’s camera.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/18/big-picture-british-fashion-week-martin-parr">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Seeing scarlet: clothes you can wear after Valentine's Day</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/gallery/2018/feb/14/seeing-scarlet-clothes-you-can-wear-after-valentines-day</link>
      <description><p>Red is the hue du jour, but that doesn’t mean it can’t live on in your wardrobe. From tops that will aid that tricky work-to-date transition to sweatshirts that can be layered now and worn solo later in the season, here are pieces to love for longer than one day</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/gallery/2018/feb/14/seeing-scarlet-clothes-you-can-wear-after-valentines-day">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The view from the front row: a history of the fashion show – photo essay</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/15/the-view-from-the-front-row-a-history-of-the-fashion-show-photo-essay</link>
      <description><p>Once, photographers were banned from fashion shows, with designers suspecting they were spies. Today, fashion shows are a multimillion-dollar global business. As London fashion week begins, we cart the evolution of the fashion show, from secret salons to the snap-happy Instagram era</p><p>Most fashion shows last less than 10 minutes, but have the power to transport an audience to another world. There’s an intensity to a great show, a distillation of a designer’s extraordinary vision. </p><p>Once upon a time, though, things were a lot humbler. The intimate salon shows of Chanel in the 1950s bear no resemblance to Karl Lagerfeld’s fully-stocked supermarket in the vast Grand Palais in 2014. The main change is scale – along with location, set production, and budget. From John Galliano’s historical dramas at Christian Dior, to Hussein Chalayan’s theatrical impossibilities and the late Alexander McQueen’s gothic, heart-stopping wonders, we chart how the fashion show developed from low-key to king.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/15/the-view-from-the-front-row-a-history-of-the-fashion-show-photo-essay">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Take cover! The balaclava’s finest fashion moments – from Calvin Klein to Kanye West</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2018/feb/14/the-balaclavas-finest-fashion-moments-calvin-klein-to-kanye-west</link>
      <description><p>Raf Simons sent the politically charged headwear down the catwalk at New York fashion week – but he’s not the first to turn it into a style statement</p><p>Not one to shy away from making his fashion shows a social and political commentary, Raf Simons continued his provocative streak at Calvin Klein at New York fashion week on Tuesday. His sartorial weapon of choice this season? <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/14/calvin-klein-rewrites-script-to-give-a-vision-of-a-turbulent-america-on-the-catwalk">The balaclava</a>.</p><p>As one of the most connotation-laden pieces of headgear – associated with war and terror, concealment and protection – it is surely no coincidence that Simons made it a focal point. Last season, his collection took its cue from classic horror stories, with American Vogue noting the US was “proving fertile territory” for Belgian-born and previously Paris-based Simons, <a href="https://www.vogue.com/fashion-shows/spring-2018-ready-to-wear/calvin-klein">“even if the country is living through its own very real horror story”</a>. This season’s collection was “the latest chapter in rewriting what an all-American icon looks like in a world of fire and fury”, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/14/calvin-klein-rewrites-script-to-give-a-vision-of-a-turbulent-america-on-the-catwalk">noted this paper</a>, albeit with less horror and more hope, according to the designer. As a result, his balaclavas swapped hostile for homemade, knitted in jolly pastel two-tone hues.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2018/feb/14/the-balaclavas-finest-fashion-moments-calvin-klein-to-kanye-west">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion">Fashion</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/new-york-fashion-week">New York fashion week</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/fashion-weeks">Fashion weeks</category>

      <description><p>New York fashion week runway featuring balaclavas and hi-vis jackets reflects what an all-American icon looks like in a world of fire and fury</p><p>Popcorn is a fashion-approved snack, so editors in New York for fashion week would have appreciated the invitation for Calvin Klein’s show: a bag of popcorn wrapped in a silver envelope.<br></p><p>The popcorn theme continued at the venue, but turned the emoji-friendly symbol for a night at the movies into something more surreal.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/14/calvin-klein-rewrites-script-to-give-a-vision-of-a-turbulent-america-on-the-catwalk">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/15/marc-jacobs-goes-back-to-the-future-with-80s-inspired-powersuits-and-prints</link>
      <description><p>Designer performing his old tricks with ‘huge flourishes’ and ‘gorgeous fabrics’ at New York show</p><p>In fashion now, real cultural currency comes from taking something woefully uncool – an Ikea bag, say, or a pair of Crocs – and giving it a catwalk makeover.</p><p>Marc Jacobs was performing this trick when the current generation of designers were yet to learn the concept of irony. And he was at it again for his autumn/winter 2018 show on Wednesday night in New York.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/15/marc-jacobs-goes-back-to-the-future-with-80s-inspired-powersuits-and-prints">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ralph Lauren brings his Caribbean beach house to Manhattan</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/12/ralph-lauren-brings-his-caribbean-beach-house-new-york-fashion-week</link>
      <description><p>Reassuringly familiar style on show, though aesthetic edges towards parody at times</p><p>Ralph Lauren is shorthand for a lifestyle. The fashion empire of the 91st richest American is built on selling a tastefully expensive American dream. So as an escapist fantasy from a chilly New York fashion week, Ralph Lauren recreated a vignette of his own holiday home in Montego Bay in a cavernous former rail depot in downtown Manhattan.<br><br>In front of an audience which included the actors Katie Holmes and Hilary Swank, the catwalk descended from the deck of a wooden beach house with white shutters, cane furniture, hurricane lamps and porthole mirrors.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/12/ralph-lauren-brings-his-caribbean-beach-house-new-york-fashion-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Fuchsia pink, leopard print and ‘Pussy Power’ bags: is this what female empowerment looks like?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/13/female-empowerment-new-york-fashion-week</link>
      <description><p>New York fashion week gave us some edgy, interesting trends, from Victoria Beckham’s shaped leather dresses to Alexander Wang’s wet-look belted coat. But does championing a cause always make for brilliant fashion?</p><p>I learned a new word at New York fashion week: gynarchy. I had to look it up; it means rule by women. Designer Prabal Gurung <a href="https://www.vogue.com/fashion-shows/fall-2018-ready-to-wear/prabal-gurung">chose it to sum up his show</a>, where sarong-inspired draping in pinks and reds referred, he said backstage, to the matriarchal <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/dec/19/china-mosuo-tribe-matriarchy">Mosuo tribe of China</a>, and to <a href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/7068875.stm">northern India’s Gulabi Gang</a>, all-female vigilantes fighting against abuse and oppression of women. The same day, Diane von Furstenberg said at her presentation that “with everything that’s happening with women right now, I personally am more committed than ever to the empowerment of women … the DVF woman through the generations has always been about a woman being in charge.” Jonathan Simkhai, meanwhile, <a href="https://www.vogue.com/fashion-shows/fall-2018-ready-to-wear/jonathan-simkhai">took inspiration from portraits of suffragettes</a>. “This moment seems particularly relevant now, when the inner strength of so many women has been at the forefront of our American consciousness,” he explained.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/13/female-empowerment-new-york-fashion-week">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2018/feb/09/madonnas-fork-facials-and-other-household-objects-you-can-use-for-skincare</link>
      <description><p>The singer has been showing off her new skincare regime on Instagram. Could spoons, clingfilm and toothbrushes be worth a go, too?</p><p>If you thought Madonna, who has been known to <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PBm5kzTYfNU">hand her worn knickers to David Letterman</a> and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/apr/13/drake-seals-coachella-with-a-kiss-from-madonna">snog Drake on stage</a>, no longer had the power to shock, think again. On Instagram, she has shared a <a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/Be3u_oGhbwt/?hl=en&amp;taken-by=madonna">video of herself receiving a facial using … forks</a>. The singer lies back while two forks are rubbed across her cheeks and under her eyes by her aesthetician, Tarin Skillets. “It really tightens the skin,” says Madonna.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2018/feb/09/madonnas-fork-facials-and-other-household-objects-you-can-use-for-skincare">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Michèle Lamy, the style queen who packs a punch</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/11/michele-lamy-the-style-queen-who-packs-a-punch</link>
      <description><p>The fashion and art world creative talks about her latest work, curating a space at Selfridges. But why has she set up a boxing ring there?</p><p>Among the wilting, late-afternoon shoppers in Selfridges’ accessories hall, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/may/13/venice-bargenale-michele-lamy">Michèle Lamy</a> stands out. Sure, the gold and diamond-encrusted teeth, fingers stained black with Japanese vegetable dye, marked forehead (she draws a thick line on each morning with eyeliner, to keep herself grounded) and diaphanous toga dress worn with platform shoes help. But it’s Lamy’s energy that glues your eyes to her as she bustles around, talking to every passerby, obliging with selfies.</p><p>Lamy, 73, who lists her job as producer, designer and creative – though she’s also a musician – is here to curate the Corner Shop. This nice little spot on the ground floor of Selfridges will be turned over to different creative types to explore the idea of modern luxury over the next five months. Lamy has created a space that focuses on her twin loves of boxing and art. Punch-bags decorated by the designers <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/sep/06/gareth-pugh-london-return-show">Gareth Pugh</a> and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/mar/06/craig-green-diy-masculinity-spring-summer-2015">Craig Green</a> and the artist <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/mar/19/sydney-biennale-review-contemporary-art-meets-sci-fi-in-wide-reaching-show">Korakrit Arunanondchai</a> sway gently in the store windows. There are two painted like sides of meat by <a href="https://www.huffingtonpost.com/annie-stein/scarlett-rouge-and-her-ma_b_4066160.html">Scarlett Rouge</a>, Lamy’s daughter with the artist <a href="http://richardnewtonartist.com/RN_artist_assets_071211/RNA_home/Richard_Newton.html">Richard Newton</a>. Versace and Off-White created exclusive boxing kit which hangs next to gear by Everlast and the <a href="https://overthrownyc.com/">Overthrow</a>, Lamy’s favourite New York gym.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/11/michele-lamy-the-style-queen-who-packs-a-punch">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Yes we clan! The rise of the frankenkilt</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/06/rise-franken-kilt-catwalk-high-street</link>
      <description><p>Catwalk labels including JW Anderson and Gucci, as well as high-street stores, have a new creation for 2018 – varying tartans spliced together to make a tradition-busting skirt</p><p>We live in tumultuous times – so why not let your skirt reflect that? The latest design classic to read 2018’s room is the kilt. In the hands of modern fashion designers, it has mutated from an item steeped in Scottish tradition to what we’re calling the ‘frankenkilt’. Rather than using one tartan all over to signpost your clan, the frankenkilt splices several together, creating a sort of anarchic feel that chimes with the zeitgeist. Think less <a href="https://i.pinimg.com/736x/d2/2a/23/d22a237bc271973cefa6e59245f49689--her-majesty-the-queen-corgi.jpg">the Queen with corgis in the Highlands</a>, more <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/jan/10/charles-jeffrey-and-the-designers-transforming-fashion-for-a-post-gender-world">designer Charles Jeffrey</a> in a kilt and bovver boots with a beauty spot.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/06/rise-franken-kilt-catwalk-high-street">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/15/women-urged-to-ditch-low-cut-gowns-and-heels-at-film-festival</link>
      <description><p>German actor Anna Brüggemann launches #NobodysDoll in push for equality on Berlin red carpet</p><p>Female actors attending this year’s Berlin film festival are being encouraged to ditch high heels and tight gowns in favour of comfortable clothes in a campaign to bring equal rights to the red carpet.<br></p><p>Under the Twitter hashtag #NobodysDoll, German actor Anna Brüggemann has said she wishes to challenge the “patriarchal gaze” women habitually face at film festivals and award ceremonies, and to inspire actors to wear what they want instead.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/15/women-urged-to-ditch-low-cut-gowns-and-heels-at-film-festival">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>‘Workplace shadowing’ reported to HM Revenue as campaigner says practice deters diversity at fashion magazine</p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/08/initiative-to-crack-down-on-unpaid-internships-launched-in-uk">Initiative to crack down on unpaid internships launched</a><br></li></ul><p>Vogue has been criticised for using unpaid interns in month-long placements despite the new editor Edward Enninful’s commitment to increasing diversity at the fashion journal.</p><p>The Condé Nast title told one potential applicant that the “workplace shadowing” role would involve “assisting the fashion features team”, including transcribing interviews, obtaining photographs and fashion samples, and helping with “online content”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/08/vogue-criticised-for-unpaid-internships">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Fashion queens: Bath exhibition shows off royal outfits</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/jan/30/fashion-queens-bath-exhibition-shows-off-royal-outfits</link>
      <description><p>From Queen Alexandra to Princess Margaret, Bath Fashion Museum explores changing tastes in its Royal Women show</p><p>More than half a century ago staff at the Fashion Museum in Bath decided the distinctive style of Alexandra, who had come from Denmark in 1863 to marry the future Edward VII, was so pared back that her lilac silk evening gown didn’t look like a proper princess’s dress at all. They added a heavy band of fringed beading to brighten up the severely plain neckline.<br></p><p>“It seems an extraordinary decision to us now,” curator Elly Summers said of the embellishment added by a predecessor when the museum moved in 1963 from Kent to the magnificent Assembly Rooms in Bath. “We wouldn’t dream of doing that now – but the alterations are part of the museum’s history, so we wouldn’t take the beading off.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/jan/30/fashion-queens-bath-exhibition-shows-off-royal-outfits">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>High street chain shuts 14 stores in drive to cut costs and boost online sales </p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/marksspencer">Marks &amp; Spencer</a> has confirmed plans to close up to 14 stores, putting nearly 500 jobs at risk in what it said were “vital” changes for its future.</p><p>The six stores to close are in Birkenhead, Bournemouth, Durham, Fforestfach in Swansea, Putney in south-west London and Redditch.     <item>
      <title>Matty Bovan – fashion's great bright hope (who still lives with his parents)</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/14/matty-bovan-fashions-great-bright-hope-who-still-lives-with-his-parents</link>
      <description><p>British fashion’s most colourful new star ditched Paris and London to return to York and start his own studio. He explains how his work mixes sci-fi dystopia with kitchen sink craft</p><p>Not all superheroes wear capes. Matty Bovan – the 27-year-old York-based designer who might just be the saviour the fashion industry needs – is more likely to be found wearing a hi-vis jacket over a white mini-dress or a mustard velvet tunic over a pair of tie-dye leggings. Bovan has an extraordinary look – part Tank Girl, part My Little Pony – and an approach to fashion that is as cheeringly unconventional.</p><p>“There seems to be a consensus among people my age,” he says, “who are trying to find a way to operate in fashion that isn’t mass production. That, in my gut, just feels right. More than ever, we need less stuff. Mass consumption, mass production can’t go on for ever.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/14/matty-bovan-fashions-great-bright-hope-who-still-lives-with-his-parents">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>‘I don’t think elegance is relevant’: Vetements’ Demna Gvasalia, the world’s hottest designer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/06/i-dont-think-elegance-is-relevant-vetements-demna-gvasalia-the-worlds-hottest-designer</link>
      <description><p>The 36-year-old Georgian, now Balenciaga’s creative director, is bored of fashion as fantasy and has eschewed the tropes of Parisian glamour for flea market catwalks and crumpled styling. Where can he go next?</p><p>To understand what makes Demna Gvasalia the hottest designer in Paris right now, you first need to forget everything you think you know about Paris. Forget <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/catherinedeneuve">Catherine Deneuve</a>, forget Jane Birkin, forget Françoise Hardy. Forget trenchcoats, silk blouses, ballet pumps and straw baskets. Forget Amélie in Montmartre and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/sex-and-the-city">Carrie Bradshaw</a> in Ladurée.</p><p>The Paris of Gvasalia, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/oct/02/demna-gvasalia-reinvigorates-balenciaga-with-strategic-disrespect">designer of Vetements and Balenciaga</a>, is not that Paris. Instead, it is the Paris you might recognise if you were gripped by the latest series of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/series/spiral-episode-by-episode-guide">gritty French police drama Spiral</a>. It is the city we glimpse through the eyes of Louise, the nanny in <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/jan/10/lullaby-leila-slimani-review">Leïla Slimani’s novel Lullaby</a>, when she makes the after-work journey from her employers’ chic 10th arrondissement home to her down-at-heel neighbourhood. It is a city of phone shops and fast food, a city where glamour means tight jeans and fake handbags, a city where background noise is a different language on every street corner, not a harmonious Édith Piaf soundtrack.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/06/i-dont-think-elegance-is-relevant-vetements-demna-gvasalia-the-worlds-hottest-designer">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Trenches to rainbows: the story of the Burberry check</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2018/feb/13/trenches-to-rainbows-the-story-of-the-burberry-check</link>
      <description><p>Burberry head Christopher Bailey will bow out this weekend, unveiling an LGBTQ+ iteration of the company’s famous pattern</p><p>On Saturday, Burberry’s chief creative officer, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/oct/31/christopher-bailey-to-cut-all-ties-with-burberry">Christopher Bailey</a>, is bringing the curtain down on his <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/oct/31/christopher-bailey-burberry-transformed-fashion-brand">17-year tenure at the British brand</a> – but not before delivering a statement-making iteration of its famous check. The <a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/BfGZdGjAYS4/?hl=en&amp;taken-by=burberry">new rainbow check</a> “is dedicated to – and in support of – some of the best and brightest organisations supporting LGBTQ+ youth around the world,” says Bailey, who has incorporated the pattern extensively into his final collection for the house, set to be unveiled in full at London fashion week this weekend. During his two decades at the top (which saw him take on the role of CEO for four years between 2013 and 2017 after <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/jan/10/profile-angela-ahrendts-apple-executive-luxury-brand">Angela Ahrendts</a> left for Apple), the designer has seen the rise, the fall – Daniella Westbrook, circa 2002 – and the subsequent rise – and rise – in popularity of the heritage signature. Here is a rundown of the Burberry signature in its hey and nay days.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/shortcuts/2018/feb/13/trenches-to-rainbows-the-story-of-the-burberry-check">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What I wore this week: hats | Priya Elan</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/02/what-i-wore-this-week-hats</link>
      <description><p>As you look in the mirror and see the creaking shadow of your dad’s eggy head approaching, it’s time to hide it with a big hat</p><p>When your remaining hair begins to resemble a small cluster of Caribbean islands on a map of the world, there are a few options. 1) Monster-era <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/michael-stipe">Michael Stipe</a>, when he went pre-emptively bald, breaking teenage hearts and ushering in the end of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/rem">REM</a> as we knew it. 2) Wear a hat.</p><p>And when I say, “Wear a hat”, I mean it literally as well as euphemistically. Because, to be blunt, we all know that when a man of A Certain Age begins to wear hats, it’s a sartorially polite way of saying, “Hey, guys, I’m doing the slow, swimming pool walk towards hair loss and I’m trying to cover it up with a <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3gOHvDP_vCs">Justin Timberlake SexyBack</a> trilby. DOYOUTHINKANYONEWILLNOTICE?!”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/02/what-i-wore-this-week-hats">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What I wore this week: a turtle neck</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/16/what-i-wore-this-week-a-turtle-neck</link>
      <description><p>The polo neck can’t stay in fashion for ever, so prepare for the inevitable with this sleeker, sportier alternative</p><p>What did we wear before polo necks were a thing? It gives me neck chills just thinking about it. A cravat? Seems unlikely, but I cannot honestly remember. I have worn a polo neck, either by itself or as a base layer under a shirt or dress, pretty much every other day this winter and last and the one before that. A polo neck is cosy without being bulky, modern without being mannered. It just works.</p><p>At some point, the polo neck will be over and I need to prepare myself for this eventuality. It will fade from favour, slip down the ratings from on-point to passable until we reach the day when bumping into someone you know while wearing one is borderline awks. <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2016/mar/30/ugg-the-look-that-refused-to-die">Like getting spotted in Uggs</a>. (A dog comes in handy here. Seriously, you can get away with wearing any old tat if you are walking a dog. A year and a half into dog ownership, I can report confidently that even if you look like you styled your outfit while escaping a burning building, no one will judge you if you have got a cockapoo with you. I don’t know why this is. It is not like a dog gets to spring a walk on you. Anyway.)</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/16/what-i-wore-this-week-a-turtle-neck">Continue reading...</a></description>
